title: Albert Bertelin
text:
Albert Bertelin (26 July 1872 – 19 July 1951) was a French composer.
Life.
Born in Paris, Bertelin studied at the <a href="Conservatoire%20de%20Paris">Conservatoire de Paris</a> where he was a pupil of <a href="Th%C3%A9odore%20Dubois">Théodore Dubois</a>, <a href="Raoul%20Pugno">Raoul Pugno</a>, <a href="Charles-Marie%20Widor">Charles-Marie Widor</a> and <a href="Jules%20Massenet">Jules Massenet</a>. In 1902 he received a 2nd prize for composition at the <a href="Prix%20de%20Rome">Prix de Rome</a>, alongside <a href="Aym%C3%A9%20Kunc">Aymé Kunc</a> and <a href="Jean%20Roger-Ducasse">Jean Roger-Ducasse</a>. He then taught <a href="counterpoint">counterpoint</a> and <a href="fugue">fugue</a> at the <a href="%C3%89cole%20C%C3%A9sar%20Franck">École César Franck</a>.
Bertelin composed one <a href="symphony">symphony</a>, one <a href="opera">opera</a>, two <a href="Oratorio">Oratorio</a>s, one <a href="Mass%20%28music%29">Mass</a>, <a href="motet">motet</a>s, a cello, a violin and a piano concerto and <a href="chamber%20music">chamber music</a> works. He also published music reviews and several musicological works and was a member of the examination jury of the Conservatoire de Paris.
Bertelin died in Paris in 1951 and was buried at <a href="P%C3%A8re%20Lachaise%20Cemetery">Père Lachaise Cemetery</a> (31st division)
